Sorry, but title is misleading to your concept.
1) Yes, explosions can happen in space. In fact, they do all the time, think of super novas.
2) Would we experience explosions in space in the same way as on Earth in an atmosphere? No, of course not. There is no (or almost none) atmosphere (read gas) in space, and therefore we will not hear it, nor feel it in a similar way as on Earth...
Wow. This was 5 seconds of useful information mixed with much more "not a good idea".

Actually, a normal explosive, something like a missile would be wonderfully effective in space. Conventional explosives don't rely entirely on heating the atmosphere to create a shockwave, like nukes. Rather the solid explosive is rapidly combusted and becomes gaseous, generating a pressure shockwave of its own.  Such a shockwave won't be very large in space and won't propagate very far, but if a conventional missile detonates just outside an enemy vessel, the pressure difference should be enough to breach the hull. This is because vessels made for travel in a vacuum are made to hold an atmosphere in/ to keep pressure in from a low pressure outside. They're NOT made to be able to resist high pressure shockwaves coming from outside. So if you were dogfighting in space, it seems that conventional explosives would be FAR more effective weapons than nuclear missiles, or such.

Of course explosions will work in space. You just have to make sure that the explosion occurs at the surface of the target. The expanding gases and schrapnel from the explosion will implode the surface structures of the target and destroy its interior structures. If they are contained inside of a pressurized cabin, that will be ruptured and experience explosive decompression which, for any living crew present and not wearing spacesuits, would be fatal.

As far as hearing the explosion is concerned, there is a way to do that. If a non nuclear explosion creates enough of an EMP or "electromagnetic pulse", it could be received by a distant antenna, amplified, and then sent to a speaker so one could "hear" the detonation. He would actually hear it far sooner than if it took place in a planet's atmosphere and had to be carried through the air as sound waves.
Nukes would still be effective because they vaporize everything around them.

The explosion in outer space is only as destructive as the matter that is emanated from its core.  Since there is no atmosphere in outer space, the force of an explosion is limited it the material that comes from the center of the blast.  Whatever particles hit you from up close will be more destructive than the same particles that might hit you from further away because they spread out and are less likely to hit you the further away they are.

Hey, enjoy watching but I have a question. You based your video on explosions in space but many of your examples dealt with science fiction movies which had fictional space vehicles exploring. Then you explained why the examples were not accurate in the face of actual laws of physics. OK. What you failed to consider is that the fictional space vehicles where pressurized and in most cases these fiction space vehicles were exploded from the inside out. In this case the pressurized vehicles would had an atmosphere to create an explosives blast wave within the vehicles themselves. The question would be what would happen to the blast wave once the outer hull of the vehicle was destroyed. If the destruction of the hull contained enough blast wave force it would be reasonable that the sound of the wave would be carried in to space. Just how far would depend on many factors, size of the vehicle, size of explosion within the vehicle, strength of the hull  and amount of pressure created before the hull failed. The list of factors are almost endless with so little to no information about a fictional space vehicle. So what could or could not be heard in space and how far would such sound carry is an unknown. But if an explosion happen in space itself no sound would be created. At less sound as we understand it.

May be worth mentioning that a nuclear explosion is actually likely to be heard if you are close enough, which could be tens to hundreds of miles. The pulse of radiated heat impinging on the outer surface of the spacecraft (or the spacesuit if you are unlucky enough to be outside) will cause some ablation of the surface causing the surface to receive a shock. If you are quite far this will sound like a faint click but closer it could be a loud bang.

This effect has been heard in nuclear tests here on earth were a relatively faint sound is heard at the instant the bomb goes off, long before the actual sound of the blast arrives (because of course the heat wave travels at the speed of light).
In space the effect would be much more pronounced because the release of energy is experienced directly rather than through the indirect heating of the air around the explosion which subsequently releases that heat at a much slower rate. The heat pulse would therefore be much sharper and higher in peak amplitude resulting in some degree of ablation even at much further distances.

I have been thinking about this sort of thing for a while (partly because I am building a model space warship and partly my job is in media/physics/engineering).

Maybe the question was wrong in the first place. Maybe the question should be can an explosion be an effective weapon.

Lets assume you use kinetic weapons (as in the TV series The Expanse), you can use high explosive rounds (shells) to do a lot of damage. If the enemy ship has an atmosphere then a round that exploded within the ship would cause shockwaves internally, potentially breaching the ships walls. Weapons would be developed to do this because it would be a known weakness. But in response ships would be developed to tackle such weapons. One option would be to vent the ships atmosphere before going into battle and the crew suiting up for battle with individual air supplies.

You actually can hear explosions in space, because the gasparticles expelled by the explosion itself travel unrestrained by airresitance at several times the speed of sound. Those particles will hit you and cause vibrations on your ships hull or your eardrums. That way, they actually even have a lot more energy than pressure waves in air, which get slowed down due to friction, so an explosion in space, depending on how close you are and therefore how many particles from the spherical expansion hit you, will not only be not silent, they will be "louder" and hit you more powerfull than in an atmosphere.

So, you almost had it at about 2:30, almost. It isn't just the shock wave that is the most powerful part of an explosion though. It is what defines the explosion itself and differentiates it from a mere burn or rapid expansion. It's all about that compressed, supersonic flow. In which case, energy is irrelevant, like the black holes vs nuke thing. It is energy density. If you get your "science" from Si-Fi movies, you will be ill equipped to understand anything about the reality of space.  For instance, movies always show spaceships barreling through asteroid fields, with hundreds of asteroids in their path, while in reality the average distance between asteroids is more than 100,000 miles even in the thickest part of the asteroid belt.  Many also show "flaming meteors" in space as well.  Do not confuse fantasy with science.

Conservation of energy.

Suppose you are 20m from a ton of TNT when it goes off. On earth a certain amount of energy will reach you. In space where is that energy going to go? 20m away in a vacuum just as much energy would hit you, probably more as there is no loss to gas in between.

OK so no shock wave, but you would still be hit by a blast of gas molecules travelling very fast, which would dump heat into your skin in a very short time period, causing your skin to ablate creating a blast wave in your skin.

Your limbs would be torn off by the reaction from the gas ablating from your skin, just as they would torn off by a shock wave on earth.

The energy of the explosion has to go somewhere and if you are in the way of it, something violent is going to happen.

THE GENIUS OF MICHELSON-MORLEY

Why can't you have sound "effects" in space? Maybe it could be literal, and they're simulated to aid the pilot/crew, for the same reason video games have sound, to help with spacial awareness. Emulating what we'd expect to hear could have a massive improvement on performance. Even here on earth in reality, we have microphones that function using light as a medium.

Explosives could have a great impact on spacecraft / stations. The pressure differential between spacecraft and outerspace itself is HUGE. Same reason you're not supposed to puncture a can of spraypaint, much less something like the welding tanks that take off across a building if the valve gets broken off.

The trick is doing enough damage to the armor/hull to get an explosive in a position where it can do damage.A sphere shaped object would make a defensive craft, not the jagged spiky things we tend to see where you could wedge something in and, boom, exert pressure and split it open.

But even at that....

Say, the thing under attack is a space station, like, gargantuan in size with atmosphere and people inside of it. Shockwaves would still travel through the trapped air inside the station, as well as through the superstructure itself much like it does on earth.

Has PhysicsGirl never done the classic, build a thing that stops an egg from breaking when dropped from X height(in gradeschool, ours was just the top of a stepladder)? Atmosphere doesn't really play a role in the destruction of the egg in that case, just raw kinetic force(easily achieved with a nuclear and other explosion, what do you think causes all that air to move in the first place...also, there's a reason scientists have tried the thought experiment of using a nuclear explosion for propulsion).

Been in a traffic accident? Amusement park rides or even an elevators display these same effects, just usually not to any kind of point of bodily injury, usually. Inertia and/or vibrations can really wreck a lot of structures making the tinies weak point to begin catastrophic breakdown. Enough vibration would turn humans inside of a station into so much pink mist, not much different than mixing a can of paint.

Earthquakes are a great example of insane destruction happening without any meaningful relationship to the atmosphere, meaning, present or not, atmosphere doesn't make a big difference.

The string's vibrating the air is a bit of a misconception, and the reality is much more complex and beautiful. The string's vibrations are transferred to the bridge and the large wooden top plate acts like the diaphragm of a speaker and the interior is the resonance chamber. The shape of the body is such to allow a wide range of frequencies to to resonate fully. Simply vibrating strings will be very quiet and dull.

Excellent video as always, but sorry, but I'm totally unconvinced. In an atmosphere, the gas created by the explosion knocks into air molecules, which pass the energy along, so the air molecules ultimately deliver the destructive energy, yes? Now in space, the gas created by the explosion doesn't have to take such a complicated route -- it can travel unimpeded to the target! Why on earth would a gas molecule arriving directly from the explosive have less energy than an air molecule that is a billion collisions removed from the original explosion? Considering all the energy that is delivered acoustically in an explosion in air, I think you've totally failed to account to where that same energy goes in the vacuum case. Perhaps an atmosphere provides improved impedance matching or keeps the energy contained in a single pulse (whereas in space maybe it arrives spread out over time?), but until a more complete argument like that is brought along, I remain unconvinced that space explosion are ineffective.

The Kessler syndrome is a scenario in which the density of objects in low Earth orbit (LEO) is high enough that collisions between objects could cause a cascade—each collision generating space debris that increases the likelihood of further collisions.  One implication is that the distribution of debris in orbit could render space activities and the use of satellites in specific orbital ranges unfeasible for many generations.  -Wikipedia

Explosives in space are also bad as they're pretty easy to detect en route...

Imagine you launch a conventional missile out of your ship towards somebody else's ship, this missile is being propelled and 'aimed' via some sort of thruster at the back. This hot thruster is pretty easy to see against the background of space (especially if the other ship is expecting to be attacked) and the missile can be avoided or shot down.

Using a laser based weapon, there's no way to avoid it... by the time you detect it, you're been hit. However, the collateral damage is pretty low and the range is also relatively low for the divergence reasons described here.

I feel like any kind of warfare in space will probably use some kind of projectile weapons... purely because of the ranges involved. If you imagine the missile scenario again but this time you fire a large (cold) metal slug at the other ship, then there's not really much way to detect that cold bit of metal flying towards you until you get hit.

This is at odds with current Naval warfare which is almost entirely aircraft and missile dominated... but in space... fighters and missiles will almost certainly be too easy to target and not cost effective. I suspect that if we ever do end up fighting in space... it'll be back to "cannons", only this time we'll be firing at ranges of 10,000 -100,000km.

Just a thought , in ukuleles and similar instruments, strings do cause the initial vibration, but because of the limited contact area with air particles have, they don't produce as much sound by themselves. What space battle movie sequences relied on proximity explosives to take out the enemies? Every one that comes to mind used projected energy weapons like laser beams. Those that used missiles typically scored direct hits to destroy an enemy. Galactica also used some kind of projectile weapons that also required a direct hit. In fact, the majority of ordinary jet fighter war movies usually show missiles that score direct hits, because it looks way cooler to the audience to see the missile hit the plane instead of blowing up nearby and using shrapnel to take out the target.Come to think of it, pressure wave damage is going to be minimal because the amount of explosives you can carry on a missile are going to be small, and at high altitude the air is so thin it might as well be in space. Most jet fighter missiles use metal rods in the warhead to create shrapnel, and don't rely on the pressure wave for damage. I think the only liberty these films take is with the sound effects in space. Other than that the weapons and how they use them are reasonably accurate.
